bibl.title: Letter from William H. Wranek, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, October 28, 1947

div1.p: Wranek requests an advance copy of Hench's speech on Walter Reed to use for publicity purposes. He is interested in the Reed materials that Hench will be bringing to the University of Virginia in connection with the speech.

div1.head: Letter from William H. Wranek, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, October 28, 1947
div1.opener:
UNIVERSITY NEWS SERVICE
William H. Wranek, Director
UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA
Charlottesville, Virginia
October 28, 1947
Dr. Philip Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, New York
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I have learned with interest from Joh Wyllie that
you will bring a part of your Walter Reed collection to the University
of Virginia on November 17 when you are to talk on the work of Dr. Reed.

This is to ask for an advanced text of your talk or for
a few quotable paragraphs to be sent in advance of your visit here.
Anything about Dr. Reed is news in Virginia and it is not difficult
to make news of it for distribution in the Latin American countries.
But in order to do this, we need to have material several days in
advance. Nothing about what you say will appear in print until after
you have spoken. What we have to do is to prepare news stories and
send them by mail to the Associated Press and United Press bureaus in
Washington. From there, they are rushed by Airmail to several points
in South and Central America, where they are distributed to the papers
in those areas. It is necessary to use mail rather than telegraph because
of the costs involved if messages are cabled to foreign points.

I have known your brother well for many years and I am
looking forward to meeting you on your visit here.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, William H. Wranek, Jr. WHW:wz
